name: 2,8-diphenylpyrido[3,2-g]quinoline
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3194

name: 2,8-diphenylpyrido[3,2-g]quinoline
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3194
Reason: The basic structure to consider is pyridine, which has a melting point of -42°C. The 2,8-diphenyl substitution involves adding phenyl groups to the pyridine ring, which significantly increases molecular weight and rigidity. Each phenyl group would also contribute to π-π interactions, further raising the melting point. Phenyl groups typically add quite a bit due to their rigidity and interactions, so adding two might be estimated to increase the melting point by about 110-130°C each. The pyridoquinoline structure contributes additional aromaticity and nitrogen atoms, which would further raise the melting point by perhaps another 30-50°C due to the increased molecular complexity and potential for additional hydrogen bonding.
